title: Documentation of `mem::uninitialized` potentially confusing for ZSTs

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: An issue proposing an enhancement or a PR with one.

labels.name: T-libs-api
labels.description: Relevant to the library API team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: A-docs
labels.description: Area: documentation for any part of the project, including the compiler, standard library, and tools

body:
I recently wanted to create a value of a zero-sized type. (Making sure that the type is `'static` and `Copy` and my API already got passed an instance of it at some point earlier.) After some thinking, I’ve ended up using `MaybeUninit::uninit().assume_init()` to create a value of the type. But I don’t feel 100% satisfied with this choice. The reason is the following: The [`mem::unitialized`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/fn.uninitialized.html) docs tell me that
* >it has the same effect as [`MaybeUninit::uninit().assume_init()`](https://doc.rust-lang.org/std/mem/union.MaybeUninit.html#method.uninit)

  and
* >the function basically cannot be used correctly


Now from my use case, I would argue that for the case of zero-sized types, `mem::unitialized` _can_ indeed be used correctly.

Is this correct? If it is, then maybe adjusting the documentation would help avoid confusion.
